There have been fourteen [Prime Ministers of Sri
Lanka](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Sri_Lanka "Prime Minister of Sri Lanka") since
the creation of the position in 1947, prior to the formation of the [Dominion
of Ceylon](/wiki/Dominion_of_Ceylon "Dominion of Ceylon"). The Prime Minister
of Ceylon was the head of the government until 1978. In 1972, the country was
named as the _Free, Sovereign and Independent Republic of Sri Lanka_ and the
position was known as the Prime Minister of Sri Lanka from then onwards. The
Prime Minister also held the unified [Ministry of External Affairs and
Defence](/wiki/Ministry_of_External_Affairs_and_Defence "Ministry of External
Affairs and Defence") until 1977, when [J.R.
Jayewardene](/wiki/Junius_Richard_Jayewardene "Junius Richard Jayewardene")'s
government adapted two separate ministries, forming the [Ministry of
Defence](/wiki/Ministry_of_Defence_\(Sri_Lanka\) "Ministry of Defence \(Sri
Lanka\)") and the [Ministry of Foreign
Affairs](/wiki/Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_\(Sri_Lanka\) "Ministry of Foreign
Affairs \(Sri Lanka\)").

In 1978, Prime Minister [J.R. Jayewardene](/wiki/Junius_Richard_Jayewardene
"Junius Richard Jayewardene") introduced new constitutional changes. The
position of the [Executive President](/wiki/President_of_Sri_Lanka "President
of Sri Lanka") was introduced, resulting in the powers of the Prime Minister
being reduced. The President became the [head of state](/wiki/Head_of_state
"Head of state") and [head of government](/wiki/Head_of_government "Head of
government"),[1] and the Prime Minister became a nominal position.[2]

Under the current [constitution of Sri Lanka](/wiki/Constitution_of_Sri_Lanka
"Constitution of Sri Lanka"), the Prime Minister is the leader of the
[Cabinet](/wiki/Cabinet_of_Sri_Lanka "Cabinet of Sri Lanka") business and also
functions as a deputy to the President. In the event a president dies in
office, the Prime Minister becomes the acting president until the Parliament
convens to elect a successor or new elections can be held to elect a new
president. This was the case in 1993, when President [Ranasinghe
Premadasa](/wiki/Ranasinghe_Premadasa "Ranasinghe Premadasa") was assassinated
and Prime Minister [Dingiri Banda Wijetunge](/wiki/Dingiri_Banda_Wijetunge
"Dingiri Banda Wijetunge") took office as President.[3]

On 28 April 2015, the Parliament approved the [Nineteenth Amendment to the
Constitution of Sri
Lanka](/wiki/Nineteenth_Amendment_to_the_Constitution_of_Sri_Lanka "Nineteenth
Amendment to the Constitution of Sri Lanka") which gives the power of the
[Government](/wiki/Government_of_Sri_Lanka "Government of Sri Lanka") to the
Prime Minister, while the [President](/wiki/President_of_Sri_Lanka "President
of Sri Lanka") remains the [head of state](/wiki/Head_of_state "Head of
state"), head of the [cabinet](/wiki/Cabinet_of_Sri_Lanka "Cabinet of Sri
Lanka"), and [Commander-in-chief](/wiki/Commander-in-chief "Commander-in-
chief").[4]

Of the fourteen prime ministers who have held office since the introduction of
the position in 1947, three have held office thrice, and one has held office
twice. Five prime ministers have gone on to become president of the country.
The current Prime Minister of Sri Lanka is [Ranil
Wickremesinghe](/wiki/Ranil_Wickremesinghe "Ranil Wickremesinghe"), since 9
January 2015.[5]

[Ranil Wickramasinghe](/wiki/Ranil_Wickramasinghe "Ranil Wickramasinghe") has
been sworn in as prime minister the most times in the country's history, on
four separate occasions (May 1993, December 2001, January 2015 and August
2015), [6] whilst [Dudley Shelton Senanayaka](/wiki/Dudley_Shelton_Senanayaka
"Dudley Shelton Senanayaka") and [Sirimavo
Bandaranayake](/wiki/Sirimavo_Bandaranayake "Sirimavo Bandaranayake") were
appointed three times.

Sirimavo Bandaranaike declared the country a republic, and its name was
changed from Ceylon to Sri Lanka.[13] Nationalized many companies in the
plantation sector and imposed restrictions on several imports. This led to the

elections of 1977, with allegations of corruption which later led to her
expulsion from Parliament.[13]

| [Sirisena](/wiki/Sirisena_cabinet "Sirisena cabinet") | [18th](/wiki/14th_Sri_Lankan_Parliament "14th Sri Lankan Parliament") | [7] | [Maithripala Sirisena](/wiki/Maithripala_Sirisena "Maithripala Sirisena") [![Maithripala- Russia \(portrait\).jpg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Maithripala-_Russia_%28portrait%29.jpg/100px-Maithripala-_Russia_%28portrait%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Maithripala-_Russia_\(portrait\).jpg)

[Sri Lanka Freedom Party](/wiki/Sri_Lanka_Freedom_Party "Sri Lanka Freedom

##
Notes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_Prime_Ministers_of_Sri_Lanka&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Notes")]

  1. The Parliament was known as the "House of Representatives" during the period of 1947–1972
  2. In 1972, the country was named "Free, Sovereign and Independent Republic of Sri Lanka", and the Parliament was named as the National State Assembly.
  3. Under the constitutional changes of 1978, the country was renamed as the "Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka", and the Parliament was referred to as "Parliament of the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka".
